seo.metaDescription: Doctor-led hand and wrist pain clinic in London. PRP, adipose cell therapy, and rehab for arthritis, TFCC tears, carpal tunnel instability, and repetitive strain.
seo.h1: Regenerative Hand & Wrist Pain Treatment in London

schema.howPerformed: Under ultrasound guidance, we target your specific hand/wrist problem: (1) For TFCC tears or ligament injuries—PRP or adipose cells injected precisely into the damaged structure to stimulate repair; (2) For arthritis—injections into affected joints to reduce inflammation and improve cushioning; (3) For trigger finger—targeted injection around the inflamed tendon sheath; (4) For De Quervain's tenosynovitis—injection into the tight thumb tendon compartment. Local anesthetic ensures comfort. Procedure takes 20-30 minutes
schema.preparation: Stop anti-inflammatory medications one week before. Arrive with clean hands—no creams or jewelry. Bring a splint if you have one (we can provide). Plan light duties for 48 hours after. For typists/musicians—arrange reduced workload for a few days. Come ready to commit to hand therapy exercises—these are crucial for lasting results
schema.followup: Wear provided splint for 5-7 days for support. Apply ice for 15 minutes every few hours on day one. Avoid heavy gripping, lifting, or repetitive hand movements for one week. Begin gentle range of motion exercises at day 3-5. Progress to strengthening under physiotherapy guidance at week 2-3. Most people return to desk work next day with splint support. Attend 6-week review to assess healing and adjust rehab
schema.outcome: Over 3-6 weeks, hand/wrist pain steadily improves. Grip strength returns. Stiffness reduces. You can type, lift, cook, play instruments, or work without that constant ache. Joints feel more stable and cushioned. Many patients avoid surgery entirely. Results last 12-18 months
schema.medicationRequired: Local anesthetic injection at treatment site. Optional oral anti-inflammatory for first 48 hours only (then avoid to allow healing)
schema.treatmentFrequency: 1-3 sessions depending on severity and condition. Trigger finger often responds to single treatment. TFCC tears or arthritis may need 2 sessions spaced 8-12 weeks apart
schema.adverseOutcome: Soreness and stiffness for 3-7 days (normal healing response). Small bruise possible. Temporary reduction in grip strength for first week. Wrist may feel puffy for a few days. Very rarely, infection (we use strict sterile technique)
contraindication: Complete tendon or ligament rupture requiring surgery
Severe carpal instability requiring surgical reconstruction
Taking blood thinners without medical clearance
Severe arthritis with no remaining joint space (may need joint replacement)
typicalTest: Ultrasound or MRI imaging of hand/wrist structures
Nerve conduction studies if carpal tunnel suspected
clinicalFindings: Chronic wrist instability from ligament injury
Repetitive strain injuries from typing/manual work
